title: John Edward Taylor (bishop)
text:
John Edward Taylor, <a href="Missionary%20Oblates%20of%20Mary%20Immaculate">OMI</a> (November 15, 1914 – September 9, 1976) was an American <a href="Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="Bishop%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">bishop</a>. The first American-born bishop to head a European diocese, he was <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Stockholm">Bishop of Stockholm</a> in <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> from 1962 to 1976.
Early life and priesthood.
Taylor was born in <a href="East%20St.%20Louis%2C%20Illinois">East St. Louis</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, to Robert and Mary (née Pohl) Taylor. After attending St. Henry’s Preparatory Seminary in <a href="Belleville%2C%20Illinois">Belleville</a>, he took his vows for the <a href="Missionary%20Oblates%20of%20Mary%20Immaculate">Oblates of Mary Immaculate</a> in 1934. He continued his studies in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, where he attended the <a href="Pontifical%20University%20of%20Saint%20Thomas%20Aquinas">Angelicum</a> and the <a href="Pontifical%20Gregorian%20University">Gregorian</a>.
On May 25, 1940, Taylor was <a href="Holy%20orders%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">ordained</a> to the <a href="Priesthood%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">priesthood</a> in Rome. He earned his Ph.D. at <a href="Ottawa%20University">Ottawa University</a> in 1941, with a thesis on the philosophy of <a href="John%20Dewey">John Dewey</a>. Returning to the United States, he taught at the Oblates’ minor seminary in Belleville before serving as <a href="Superior%20%28hierarchy%29">superior</a> of Oblate seminaries in <a href="Carthage%2C%20Missouri">Carthage</a>, <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a> (1947-1953) and in <a href="Pass%20Christian%2C%20Mississippi">Pass Christian</a>, <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a> (1953-1958).
In 1958, Taylor was chosen to lead a <a href="Catholic%20missions">mission</a> to revive the <a href="Catholic%20Church%20in%20Greenland">Catholic Church in Greenland</a>. He first established a headquarters in the <a href="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> suburb of <a href="Herlev">Herlev</a> and, in 1960, became the first Catholic priest to settle in Greenland since the <a href="Reformation">Reformation</a>.
Bishop of Stockholm.
On July 2, 1962, Taylor was appointed <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Stockholm">Bishop of Stockholm</a> in <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> by <a href="Pope%20John%20XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">episcopal consecration</a> on the following September 21 from Archbishop <a href="Bruno%20Heim">Bruno Heim</a>, with Bishops <a href="Jacques%20Mangers">Jacques Mangers</a> and <a href="Fulton%20J.%20Sheen">Fulton J. Sheen</a> serving as co-<a href="consecrator">consecrator</a>s, in the <a href="Blue%20Hall">Blue Hall</a> of <a href="Stockholm%20City%20Hall">Stockholm City Hall</a>. The event was the first consecration of a Catholic bishop in Sweden since 1531.
During his tenure, the estimated number of Catholics in the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Stockholm">Diocese of Stockholm</a> (which covers all of Sweden) rose from 27,000 to 75,000, and the number of priests rose from 64 to 97. He also established a priests’ council, a Catholic education commission, and an ecumenical commission. He served as chairman of the <a href="Scandinavian%20Bishops%20Conference">Scandinavian Bishops Conference</a> from 1970 to 1973.
Taylor attended all four sessions of the <a href="Second%20Vatican%20Council">Second Vatican Council</a> between 1962 and 1965. He presented Catholic peace activist <a href="Tom%20Cornell">Tom Cornell</a> with the commemorative medal given to each bishop who participated in the Council, in acknowledgment of "the role that the <a href="Catholic%20Peace%20Fellowship">Catholic Peace Fellowship</a>, together with the <a href="Catholic%20Worker">Catholic Worker</a>, played at the Council – the role of invisible Council Father."
Later life.
Following an operation to remove a cerebral tumor, Taylor resigned as Bishop of Stockholm on June 3, 1976. He retired to a nursing home run by the <a href="Bridgettines">Bridgettines</a> in <a href="Djursholm">Djursholm</a>, where he died a few months later on September 9, at the age of 61.
